channel.title: The New York Times Trends
channel.description: 用中文浏览纽约时报热门报道

item.title:
A fire broke out early Friday morning at a complex in southern Ukraine that is home to Europe’s largest nuclear power plant, after Russian troops fired on the area, Ukraine’s foreign minister said.
Follow our live updates. https://t.co/L1Ph1KXHmD

More than 800 medical students are stranded at their university in the city of Sumy in northeastern Ukraine, officials said, after Russian forces hindered access to roads and trains. The students are mostly from African countries and India. https://t.co/d0VTAgAdTW

A phone conversation between President Emmanuel Macron and President Vladimir Putin on Thursday offered little hope that the fighting in Ukraine would abate soon. The French president's office warned that Putin seems determined to invade the whole country. https://t.co/r3b02RMwVE

Ikea and TJX, the owner of TJ Maxx and Marshalls, became the latest retailers to halt business operations in Russia, joining the growing number of Western companies condemning the country’s invasion of Ukraine. https://t.co/n7ePLY1DHl

The U.S. has announced an array of new sanctions on Russian elites and oligarchs, including President Vladimir Putin’s spokesman. The sanctions include travel bans and seizures of assets. https://t.co/QfueP2EmKe

Ukrainians fleeing Russia’s invasion of their country will be offered temporary protection in the European Union, its ministers decided on Thursday, as the exodus from Ukraine surpassed a million people. https://t.co/A8aBLcG35E https://t.co/4vhmpI0kxT
Breaking News: The Biden administration is offering temporary protected status to Ukrainians who were living in the U.S. without documentation as of March 1. https://t.co/xv2CVLxbd8

Flag manufacturers across the U.S. are cutting and sewing blue and yellow fabric as fast as possible to keep up with the surge in demand for the flag of Ukraine since the country was invaded by Russia last week. https://t.co/z4sr4lnSyF
The International Chess Federation is working to distance itself from Russia, canceling tournaments and disqualifying grandmasters who support the invasion of Ukraine. https://t.co/hWbQv48gxq

One million Ukrainians have become refugees in the week since Russian forces invaded, the UN said, and another million people have been displaced or are on the move inside the country. https://t.co/ZlyGriRfBn https://t.co/mSXfhblDOa

President Vladimir Putin for the first time personally acknowledged Russian losses in the war in Ukraine in a video televised on Russian state media on Thursday. He also claimed the military operation was proceeding according to plan.
Follow live updates: https://t.co/NGBxrYwszM https://t.co/FMX2Gkm4RJ

The BBC is reviving its use of shortwave radio to broadcast in Ukraine and in parts of Russia. The tactic, popularized during World War II, uses frequencies that can travel for long distances and be accessible on portable radios. https://t.co/kAT4fvWUjB
Hundreds of people waited in long lines for food in Kharkiv as Ukraine warned of a humanitarian crisis caused by Russia’s invasion. https://t.co/WSF413VC1l https://t.co/jwlsQZBT66

Russians aren't getting enough accurate information about the invasion of Ukraine to really understand it, @kadriliik told @EllenBarryNYT. Listen to the conversation: https://t.co/1tYJEIsbvW https://t.co/qxLVs20RwF

The U.S. surgeon general formally requested that big tech platforms provide information about the scale of Covid misinformation on their sites.
The notice asked for details of “exactly how many users saw or may have been exposed to” Covid misinformation. https://t.co/cdHuNkGfwz

The Ukrainian military is conducting a hugely effective and "mobile" defense, using their innate knowledge of their home turf to stymie Russian forces on multiple fronts, the top military adviser to President Biden said early Thursday. https://t.co/8yxOoqGMaR

Breaking News: The Russian soprano Anna Netrebko won’t sing at the Metropolitan Opera for at least two seasons after the company demanded she distance herself from Vladimir Putin. https://t.co/N0K36XOPHM

The Biden administration is preparing more sanctions aimed at Russian oligarchs as the U.S. seeks to put more pressure on Russia’s economy and allies of President Vladimir Putin, a person familiar with the plans said. https://t.co/EeBewqQsOL

Video verified by The New York Times shows the bombardment of Chernihiv, Ukraine, on Thursday. As smoke cleared from the attack — which hit near apartments, pharmacies and a hospital — people are seen running in the street. https://t.co/J1MhFcNCnm https://t.co/S2l2MBkxaF

Video verified by The New York Times shows two warplanes flying at low altitude moments before launching an airstrike on an apartment complex in a city just outside Kyiv on Wednesday. The Ukrainian police said it was not yet clear if there were casualties. https://t.co/2JeCVcJMr1

A 28-year-old man was arrested and charged with committing hate crimes in a two-hour spree of attacks on seven women of Asian descent in Manhattan over the weekend. The attacks were another example of a grim wave of violence against Asian Americans. https://t.co/ABN59Gves4

Ukrainians are facing a deepening humanitarian crisis as Russian forces bombard urban areas, reducing basic services to rubble.
A million people have become refugees in the past week, the UN said, as packed evacuation trains carry them west. https://t.co/6SSljyqY1Z https://t.co/P6xd6HpHMl

President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine portrayed invading Russian troops as directionless, even as Russia captured the city of Kherson.
"They don't know why they are here," he said of Russian soldiers. https://t.co/ciNzaBZRMY https://t.co/U3dtxkZ6iu

Russian soldiers destroyed bridges and obstructed the food supply in the southern Ukrainian city of Mariupol, its mayor said. He described “a blockade” that has prevented residents from evacuating. https://t.co/rLChbhNmdd https://t.co/nMBXmFTb4k

While casualty figures in wartime are unreliable, and Ukraine has put the total of Russian dead in the thousands, Moscow acknowledged a death toll of 498 in seven days of fighting — the largest in any of its military operations since the war in Chechnya. https://t.co/EHaDzZEgde

Video verified by The New York Times captured the bombardment of a residential area in Chernihiv, a key northern Ukrainian city.
The footage shows projectiles landing, followed by explosions. As the smoke clears, people are seen running in the street. https://t.co/O1ky3Sy7WI

The Kremlin has forced Echo of Moscow, Russia’s flagship liberal radio station, to shut down.
The station was a symbol of freedom after the Soviet Union collapsed, and has now become an emblem of the crackdown on dissent amid Russia's invasion of Ukraine. https://t.co/9NPa7rHRnb

France seized a yacht belonging to Igor Sechin, who runs the Russian state oil giant Rosneft and is a close associate of President Vladimir Putin, as part of sanctions imposed on Russia over the war in Ukraine.
Follow our updates. https://t.co/3nsFkMKBay

H&M Group, one of the biggest clothing sellers in the world, temporarily stopped all sales in Russia, the retailer said, joining a growing list of companies rethinking their ties to the country after its invasion of Ukraine. https://t.co/OMguSwkIxI

The Jan. 6 panel said in a court filing that there was evidence to conclude that Donald Trump might have engaged in a criminal conspiracy to try to stay in office. https://t.co/usSZCVDW6R https://t.co/jxSWBulqH6

In Opinion
"The invasion of Ukraine is a waking nightmare, horrible and absurd. And it’s being done in our name," Alexey Kovalev, an editor at the independent Russian news outlet Meduza, writes in a guest essay. https://t.co/fwwN4veu3A

The EU is expected to grant temporary protection to all Ukrainians fleeing Russia’s invasion. Europe's embrace stands in stark contrast to 2015, when people fleeing conflict in the Middle East and Africa were met with violent anti-immigrant backlash. https://t.co/SeKrYew3oc
As Russian forces close in on Kyiv, life is being brought into the world in the makeshift maternity ward of a hospital basement. https://t.co/6sryM3mtPX https://t.co/0tG2q6FXzF

Autherine Lucy Foster, the first Black student at the University of Alabama, has died at 92. Her time there lasted only three days; attacked by mobs, she was suspended and then expelled. Today, a campus building is named in her honor. https://t.co/sKqm6qysZF

President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine portrayed invading Russian troops as directionless, even as Russia captured the city of Kherson.
"They don't know why they are here," he said of Russian soldiers. https://t.co/lwNbJZPkB4 https://t.co/LSZAXtX7VV

Breaking News: Michael Madigan, who wielded power among Democrats in Illinois for decades, was indicted on federal racketeering charges and accused of using his office for personal gain. https://t.co/jfLFV3uw0R

The Ukrainian government has been receiving free assistance in its legal and public relations campaigns against Russia from influential Washington firms, and more offers of free help have been rolling in, according to people familiar with the arrangements. https://t.co/VahGRLN9Py

Senator Tim Kaine of Virginia, who said he still experiences mild symptoms of long Covid, introduced a new bill with Senators Tammy Duckworth of Illinois and Ed Markey of Massachusetts, that calls for expanding and accelerating research into long Covid. https://t.co/bJUr597GPt
Breaking News: In a court filing, the Jan. 6 panel said there was evidence to conclude that Donald Trump may have committed crimes to try to stay in office. https://t.co/PawwQom91U

Vladimir Potanin, one of the richest men in Russia and a Guggenheim Museum donor for decades, is stepping down as a museum trustee, the latest oligarch affected by widening outrage over the war in Ukraine. https://t.co/Knwgox7ici

As Russia’s war in Ukraine intensifies, about one-third of Russians appear to oppose the invasion, Denis Volkov of @levada_ru told @EllenBarryNYT. But that may not matter to the Kremlin. Listen to the conversation: https://t.co/dTlBxCyqW4 https://t.co/1G2M7NQpPH

The Justice Department announced a task force to go after billionaire oligarchs who have aided President Vladimir Putin in his invasion of Ukraine, part of an effort by the U.S. to seize and freeze the assets of those who have violated sanctions. https://t.co/DoWEiPk5UT

As many as 15,000 people, including many children, have taken refuge in the Kyiv subway system to escape bombing and artillery fire as Russian forces advance on Ukraine’s capital, according to officials in Kyiv. https://t.co/fyGnPUknJN https://t.co/Wbbsz90Kig

The Biden administration on Wednesday ramped up restrictions on exporting certain technologies to Russia and Belarus. They said it would degrade the ability to wage war on Ukraine and would prevent Belarus from channeling forbidden goods to Russia. https://t.co/JgPkfbNBgI

As many as 15,000 people, most of them women and children, have taken up residence in Kyiv’s subway system as Russian forces attack, Kyiv's mayor said Wednesday. And the subway is not the only subterranean refuge. https://t.co/Zh3jA4f6vc

Husbands comfort their wives. Nurses tend to newborns. A mother sees her baby for the first time.
As Russian forces close in on Kyiv, life is being brought into the world in the makeshift maternity ward of a hospital basement. https://t.co/oMczlt9I4t https://t.co/VACyy5YtXA
Prime Minister Boris Johnson on Wednesday faced pressure from lawmakers to take specific measures to expose the assets of Russia's oligarchs in Britain. https://t.co/FT1rHn7s2S

Russian soldiers, one holding grenades above his head, walked through an angry, shouting crowd in Konotop, Ukraine. In another video, the city's mayor asked the crowd to make a decision: Surrender or fight?
See the footage, verified by the New York Times: https://t.co/bGd7Z4lc4W

“It’s a sea change,” Anne-Claire Legendre, the spokeswoman for the French Foreign Ministry, said of the world's response to Russia's invasion of Ukraine. “A new world has defied Putin, the master of propaganda.” https://t.co/RBNbxXCBEq
Oracle, the enterprise software company, said Wednesday it had “suspended all operations” in Russia in response to the country’s invasion of Ukraine. https://t.co/oFvmIkiWU1
